title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: The only " business man " living at the Ferry was the one who leased the Ferry Hills, and was extensively connected with the mail service and posting, and kept the inn, as mentioned  (p. 55).

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;

snippet: "That one," said the herd, " is for sheep, and this one for cattle"; which had some truth in it, as I found on meeting the dog the same year in Leith, when I asked its master if he had not lost it latel)^ Yes, he said, he had lost it on the Ferry Hills.

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: I have already said (p. 13) that "the Ferry Hills, east of the road," extending  to Caroline's Nose (or " the Caroline Knowes," as it was frequently  expressed), were "clothed throughout in the finest of pasture, and (one might say) covered with horses, cattle and sheep."

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: From the part of the Ferry Hills alluded to, and looking towards the west, on the same side of the firth, the ruins of Rosyth Castle present a striking object for contemplation.

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: First we showed her the Ferry Hills, east of the road, clothed throughout in the finest of pasture, and (one might say) covered with horses, cattle and sheep ; then the various scenes in all directions ; and after that Port Laing sands, the salmon stake-nets there, and the place where some snow was always found after it had disappeared everywhere else, in consequence of it slipping off the hill and accumulating  in the hollow below.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: How beautiful is Dunfermline seen from the Ferry Hills, its grand old abbey towering ov^er all, seeming to hallow the city and to lend a charm and dignity to the lowliest tenement.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: When the top of the Ferry Hills was reached we saw the town, all as dead as if the holy Sabbath lay upon it, without one evidence  of life.
